]
Darkies all work while the white men play,/Loading up boats with the bales of cotton/ Gittin' no rest till de Judgement Day. /Git yourself a brand new gal, /A lovin' baby who's the apple of your eye,/ Coal Black Rose or High Brown Sal,/ They always bake the sparrer and the chickin pie!/ Darkies all work on the Mississippi,/Darkies all work while the white folks play/ Loadin' those boats with the bales of cotton, / Gittin' no rest till the Judgement Day.
[steamboat whistle sounds offscreen and picture changes to a shot of the showboat arriving in the distance and the black chorus singing onscreen]
Cotton Blossom, Cotton Blossom,/ Long to see you growin' free,/When they pack you on the levee/ you're a heavy load to me!/ Cotton Blossom, Cotton Blossom/ Long to see you growin' wild...
There's the show boat!

[singing]
On the levee, you're too heavy/ For this poor black child!
[the workers run to the dock. The calliope plays as we see shots of townspeople running toward the dock. Then band plays]

[on the boat, over the noise of the band]
Andy! Andy!
Goshamighty, woman, what's eatin' ya?
Did you tell the band to wear their new uniforms?
Course I did. What did we get 'em fer?
You'll have 'em all ruined!
Goshamighty, well, look, they're waitin' for us. That's our public! Hiya, public!
[He waves and the crowd cheers]
Did you understand the moral of the play, my dear?
Oh,sure, ma. Did you see how he kissed her?
Yes! I hardly thought that was in the best of taste!

[singing]
I gits weary / An' sick o' tryin' / I'm tired o' livin' / An' scared o' dyin' / But Ol' Man River / He jes' keeps rollin' along!
You wouldn't call a man a white man that had Negro blood in him, would you?
No, I wouldn't; not in Mississippi. One drop of Negro blood makes you a Negro in these parts!
I just shell them peas.
You ain't pickin' them up.
No, but I could've if you didn't. I could do a lotta things if it was necessary.
Then why don't you?
It ain't necessary.
I could say that my name was Bonaparte, and show you Napoleon's tomb; that wouldn't make him my grandfather would it?
Seein' as how this is the first show we ever seed, you better give me and my friend Zebe here the best two seats in the the-ay-ter.
But this is Confederate money!
That's the kind they use in the hills, it's as good as yours, ain't it?
But this quarter - it don't ring!
Whaddaya want for two bits - sleigh bells?

I never complained. I've lived like this half the time - washing clothes, cooking food over a gas jet, but I loved him. And if all that came with him, I was willing to take care of it. I thought he knew that.
(singing) Fish gotta swim, birds gotta fly, I gotta love one man till I die, Can't help lovin' dat man of mine.

[singing]
Oh, I can't explain. It's surely not his brain That makes me thrill. I love him Because he's - I don't know... Because he's just my Bill!

[to Magnolia]
Once a girl like you starts to love a man, she don't stop so easy.
Well, couldn't you stop loving Steve if he treated you mean?
No, honey, no matter what he did.

[referring to the idea of keeping an eye on Julie]
Say, I'm a doorman, not a nursemaid!
We don't usually pick up actors off the wharves, but we can't be choosy right now!
Madam, your courtesy is only exceeded by your charm.
Julie, let's hear the new song, will you?

[half-drunk]
I don't feel like singin'.
Oh, don't you? What DO you feel like doing, Duchess?
I feel like going off on a tear!

[showing Julie's picture to the Sheriff]
See that?
Why that's Miss Julie LaVerne, ain't it?
Yeah, that's what she calls herself, ever since she got married to a white man!
What d'ya mean?
Frank, come over here; I want you to hear this. You too, Ellie.
Sit down and explain yourself. And you make sure you know what you're talkin' about.
[Parthy has just gone to bed, and Cap'n Andy is flirting with three chorus girls in a hotel lobby]
Pops, who was that?
That was Parthenia, my wife.
Oh, my mistake!
No... mine!

[saying farewell to Kim before he deserts her and Magnolia]
And when I'm gone, you'll think of me, won't you?
Of course I will. And when you're gone, I always do what you tell me.
What was that?
Don't you remember? Make-believe!

[touched and on the verge of tears]
That's right. I gave you a system for having everything you want.
Queer how a woman goes to pieces over a man. She was the best bet in Chicago until that curly-haired tramp threw her down.
He's a murderer!
Mama!
You're letting my daughter marry a murderer!
Who's the murderer?
That Ravenal! He killed a man.
Gay!
Then why ain't he in jail, or hanged?
The jury figured the gentleman he killed oughta went anyhow.
Andy Hawks, are you going to stand there and let your only child marry a murderer?
Oh don't be so narrow minded, Mrs. Hawks, I killed a man myself once.
You killed?
Yes, me. Now, are you comin' with us, or ain't you? They're going to be married.
Married to a murderer! Oh!
[she faints]
She's fainted.
Are you sure?
She's out.
Good! Now we'll go on with the wedding.
Mercy! Something must be on fire the way Queenie's running
Now what's the trouble, Queenie?
There's a powerful fine lookin' fella' out here, wants to know if you all could accommodate him by takin' him down the river fuh as the next town.
We don't carry no passengers - fine lookin' did you say? Is he an actor?
Might be. But he seems more like the kind of a gentleman it's a pleasure to wait on.
And if you can play the parts to my satisfaction, I'll give you 15 dollars a week, and a chance to see the world.
I've seen it.

[singing]
Who cares if my boat goes upstream? Or if the gale bids me go with the river's flow? I drift along with my fancy; sometimes I thank my lucky stars my heart is free...

[as Ellie looks admiringly after Gaylord]
What are you lookin' at?
Bet he's some aristocrat.
Yeah? Look at the cracks in his shoes.

[singing]
... and other times I wonder, where's the mate for me?
Nolie, what's the matter? Is Gay hurt?
No. Ellie, you read it. I may believe it if I hear somebody else say it.
Hey, where'd you get that gold brooch?
You mean this scrumptious piece o' jewelry?
Yeah, where'd you get it?
It was give tuh me.
Who give it to you?
Ask me no questions and I'll tell you no lies!
[she walks off, laughing heartily]

[muttering]
I know who give it to you and she's gonna be sorry, too. All right, Miss Julie LaVerne, if that's how you feel about me...
[he rips the photo of Julie out of its frame on the stand, but is seen by Windy]

[the actors are performing the play "The Parson's Bride" on the show boat. Rubber Face, the prop and sound effects man, mistakenly moos like a cow instead of doing a doorbell sound effect]
Moo!

[in character as Miss Lucy]
Ah, there's the bell. It must be Parson Brown at last!

[enters in character as Parson Brown]
Good evening, Miss Lucy! I was absorbed in meditation and did not realize night had fallen.
The days are growing shorter, Hamilton, but they're long when one is waiting!
As I came across the field I saw the cattle driven home by your faithful dog.

[growing ever louder]
Mooo! MOOOO!
[Ravenal rolls his eyes in exasperation]

[to Rubber face]
Shut up!
